question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_on_demand_package_id()] [Package Availability Attack] If package ID is set to a package being upgraded or marked deprecated, can this cause all oracle operations to fail until package state stabilizes? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: init()] [State Object Collision] If multiple deployments of this module create separate State objects, can confusion about which is canonical cause oracle read failures? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_oracle_queue_id()] [Queue Rotation Attack] If legitimate oracle operations expect oracle queue to remain stable during multi-step operations, can an attacker update queue mid-operation to cause different price reads in same logical operation? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_guardian_queue_id()] [Guardian Downgrade] Can an attacker replace a strict guardian queue with a permissive one to bypass security checks that would normally reject suspicious oracle updates? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: on_demand_package_id()] [Package Authenticity Bypass] If this ID is used to verify Switchboard package authenticity, can replacing it allow injection of oracle data from non-Switchboard sources masquerading as legitimate? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_on_demand_package_id()] [Circular Package Reference] Can setting on_demand_package_id to create circular dependency chains break package verification logic in consuming modules? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Struct: State] [Single Shared State Assumption] If consuming code assumes single canonical State object but multiple exist (from re-inits or different deployments), can this cause oracle data inconsistency? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: init()] [OTW Claim Bypass] The one-time witness (ON_DEMAND) is claimed via package::claim_and_keep() but not used elsewhere - can an attacker create a fake package with same module name to confuse package verification? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_oracle_queue_id()] [ID Type Confusion] Sui IDs are just addresses - can an attacker pass an address that's valid but points to wrong object type, and will Sui runtime catch this before causing crashes? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: oracle_queue()] [Object Table Lookup] If consuming code uses oracle_queue ID to look up dynamic fields or object tables, can invalid IDs cause table lookup errors that crash transactions? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: init()] [Transfer Failure Handling] AdminCap transfer to ctx.sender() - if sender is a shared object or doesn't exist, what happens and can this brick the admin capability? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Functions: set_oracle_queue_id() + oracle_queue()] [Getter/Setter Race] Can an attacker call setter to update oracle_queue while Volo Vault is in the middle of multi-step oracle read operation using getter, causing inconsistent price data? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Functions: set_guardian_queue_id() + guardian_queue()] [Guardian Swap Attack] Can guardian queue be swapped between guardian verification and oracle data acceptance to bypass guardian checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Functions: set_on_demand_package_id() + on_demand_package_id()] [Package Verification TOCTOU] Can package ID be changed after package verification check but before oracle data usage to inject malicious oracle values? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Functions: All Setters] [Coordinated State Corruption] Can an attacker atomically call all three setters in one transaction to create completely malicious oracle configuration that bypasses any single-field validation? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Functions: init() + Setters] [Initialization Race] Can an attacker front-run legitimate setup by calling setters with malicious IDs immediately after init() but before legitimate configuration? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: oracle_queue()] [Vault Value Manipulation] If Volo Vault reads oracle_queue to get asset prices for vault value calculation, can replacing this ID cause vault to use manipulated prices enabling theft via inflated share values? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_oracle_queue_id()] [Health Limiter Bypass] If Navi health limiter uses oracle prices from this queue, can replacing queue with one returning favorable prices bypass health factor checks and enable over-leverage? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: guardian_queue()] [Loss Tolerance Exploit] If guardian queue is supposed to prevent vault losses beyond tolerance, can replacing it with permissive guardian allow losses to exceed configured tolerance? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: on_demand_package_id()] [Adaptor Trust Bypass] If Volo adaptors (Navi, Suilend, Cetus, Momentum) verify oracle package ID before accepting prices, can changing this ID mid-operation bypass adaptor security checks? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_oracle_queue_id()] [Reward Manager Price Manipulation] If vault reward manager uses oracle prices to calculate APY or reward distribution, can oracle manipulation via queue replacement enable theft of accumulated rewards? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: oracle_queue()] [Deposit/Withdraw Price Attack] Can attacker manipulate oracle queue to inflate prices during deposits (getting more shares) then deflate during withdrawals (extracting more assets)? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_guardian_queue_id()] [Operation Status Bypass] If guardian queue prevents operations during abnormal vault status, can replacing guardian allow operations to proceed when vault should be frozen? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_oracle_queue_id()] [Sandwich Attack with Oracle] Can an attacker sandwich a user's vault operation by: (1) replacing oracle queue with favorable prices, (2) user operation executes with manipulated prices, (3) restore original queue, profiting from price difference? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/on_demand.move] [Function: set_guardian_queue_id()] [Guardian-Oracle Collusion] If attacker controls both a malicious oracle queue and guardian queue, can they coordinate to inject arbitrary prices that pass guardian validation? (Critical)
